com.badlogic.gdx.graphics
Class BitmapFont

java.lang.Object
  com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.BitmapFont

public class BitmapFont
extends java.lang.Object

Loads and renders AngleCode BMFont files. The bitmap font consists of 2 files: the .fnt file which must be saved with text encoding (not xml or binary!) and the bitmap file holding the glyphs, usually in .png format.

This implementation currently only supports a single glyph page.

To draw text with this class you need to call one of the draw() methods together with a SpriteBatch. The SpriteBatch must be in rendering mode, that is, SpriteBatch.begin() must have been called before drawing.

Text can be cached in a BitmapFontCache for faster rendering of static text.

A BitmapFont loaded from a file is managed. dispose() must be called to free the backing texture when no longer needed. A BitmapFont loaded using a sprite is managed if the sprite's texture is managed. Disposing the BitmapFont disposes the sprite's texture, which may not be desirable if the texture is still being used elsewhere.

The code is heavily based on Matthias Mann's TWL BitmapFont class. Thanks for sharing, Matthias! :)

Author:
Nathan Sweet , Matthias Mann

Constructor Detail

BitmapFont

public BitmapFont()
Creates a new BitmapFont using the default 15pt Arial font included in the gdx jar file. This is here to get you up and running quickly.

BitmapFont

public BitmapFont(FileHandle fontFile,
                  Sprite sprite)

BitmapFont

public BitmapFont(FileHandle fontFile,
                  FileHandle imageFile,
                  boolean flip)
Creates a new BitmapFont instance based on a .fnt file and an image file holding the page with glyphs. Currently only supports single page AngleCode fonts.

Parameters:
fontFile - The font file
imageFile - The image file
flip - If true, the glyphs will be flipped for use with a perspective where 0,0 is the upper left corner.
Method Detail

draw

public int draw(SpriteBatch spriteBatch,
                java.lang.CharSequence str,
                int x,
                int y,
                Color color)
Draws the given string at the given position with the given color. You can only call this between SpriteBatch.begin()/ SpriteBatch.end().

Parameters:
spriteBatch - The SpriteBatch to use
str - The string
x - The x position of the left most character
y - The y position of the left most character's top left corner
color - The color
Returns:
the width of the rendered string

drawMultiLineText

public int drawMultiLineText(SpriteBatch spriteBatch,
                             java.lang.CharSequence str,
                             int x,
                             int y,
                             Color color)
Draws the given string at the given position with the given color. The position coincides with the top left corner of the first line's glyph. This method interprets new lines. You can only call this between SpriteBatch.begin()/ SpriteBatch.end().

Parameters:
spriteBatch - The SpriteBatch to use
str - The string
x - The x position of the left most character of the first line
y - The y position of the left most character's top left corner of the first line
color - The color
Returns:
The height of the rendered string

drawMultiLineText

public int drawMultiLineText(SpriteBatch spriteBatch,
                             java.lang.CharSequence str,
                             int x,
                             int y,
                             Color color,
                             int alignmentWidth,
                             BitmapFont.HAlignment alignment)
Draws the given string at the given position with the given color. The position coincides with the top left corner of the first line's glyph. The method interprets new lines. You can only call this between SpriteBatch.begin()/ SpriteBatch.end().

You can specify the horizontal alignment of the text with the alignmentWidth and alignment parameters. The first parameter specifies the width of the rectangle the text should be aligned in (x to x + alignmentWidth). The second parameter specifies the alignment itself.

Parameters:
spriteBatch - The SpriteBatch to use
str - The string
x - The x position of the left most character of the first line
y - The y position of the left most character's top left corner of the first line
color - The color
alignmentWidth - The alignment width
alignment - The horizontal alignment
Returns:
The height of the multiline text

drawWrappedText

public int drawWrappedText(SpriteBatch spriteBatch,
                           java.lang.CharSequence str,
                           int x,
                           int y,
                           Color color,
                           int wrapWidth)
Draws the given string at the given position with the given color. The position coincides with the top left corner of the first line's glyph. This method interprets new lines and causes the text to wrap at spaces based on the given wrapWidth. You can only call this between SpriteBatch.begin()/ SpriteBatch.end().

Parameters:
spriteBatch - The SpriteBatch to use
str - The string
x - The x position of the left most character of the first line
y - The y position of the left most character's top left corner of the first line
color - The color
wrapWidth - The wrap width
Returns:
the height of the rendered string

drawWrappedText

public int drawWrappedText(SpriteBatch spriteBatch,
                           java.lang.CharSequence str,
                           int x,
                           int y,
                           Color color,
                           int wrapWidth,
                           BitmapFont.HAlignment alignment)
Draws the given string at the given position with the given color. The position coincides with the top left corner of the first line's glyph. This method interprets new lines and causes the text to wrap at spaces based on the given wrapWidth. You can only call this between SpriteBatch.begin()/ SpriteBatch.end().

You can specify the horizontal alignment of the text within the wrapWidth by using the alignment parameter.

Parameters:
spriteBatch - The SpriteBatch to use
str - The string
x - The x position of the left most character of the first line
y - The y position of the left most character's top left corner of the first line
color - The color
wrapWidth - The wrap width
Returns:
the height of the rendered string

getBaseLine

public int getBaseLine()
Returns:
The baseline offset, which is the distance from the drawing position to the line that most glyphs sit on

The line height, which is the distance from one line of text to the next

The cap height, which is the typical height of uppercase characters
